The near extinction of the white-backed vulture is one of the great animal tragedies of the Indian subcontinent. These magnificent birds will no doubt survive in aviaries, but I'm not sanguine about their survival in the wild, and share the BNHS secretary's perspective.

Although, other veterinary NSAIDs are less harmful to vultures, they are often administered to cattle and water buffalo at two or three times their normal dosage, at which they do become harmful. Indeed my suspicion is that diclofenac was already over-used, not just on cows before death, but also on ageing draft animals (horses, oxen) in order to push them beyond the limits of their declining physical output.
PS A  handful of their dying might have been on diclofenac, but the Parsis in mid- to late-20th century India never had the numbers to trigger anything other than a few local avian fatalities.

I personally consider this more like a reincarnation or transforming into another organism, rather than being immortal. The jellyfish technically are not living forever, they are simply going backwards in their life cycle. How do we know that this reincarnated jellyfish is not a different jellyfish? If it is different then this is not truly immortality. I think before scientists go any further into trying to apply this to human beings, they should answer the question first.

I am reluctant to think that we will even be able to isolate this "immortality" gene and somehow apply it to humans. We have a brain and we are much more complicated organisms. Though I did find it quite shocking we supposidly share a large amount of genetic similarity with the jellyfish. Why is mankind so obsessed with immortality? Is it really necessary for us to live forever? An even if we are able to take this gene and figure out how to replicate it in humans, what kind of quality of life would that be? Our bodies would be healthy and living, however our minds would begin to deteriorate at some point. I would never want to do that to myself.

What is immortality? Immortality is living one's life without pause, with memories of it all. However, what does this jellyfish present? It presents a life of identical organisms knitted together. Immortality is not about new lives one after the other, it's about the continuous and infinite life of one individual. To be realistic, if bringing this sort of "immortality" was even feasible, what would it cause? It would bring about people trying to extend their own bloodlines for as long as possible and the want for eternal heritage. Surely, this is not where the world wants to head. To have repeats of people over generations may sound amazing with geniuses, but to be honest, if a person that wreaked havoc on the world once came back again, could this lead to more deaths and violence? Could anyone imagine thousands, if not millions of terrorists raised only to destroy countries and governments? Anarchy would be wide spread and at large.
This jellyfish is not the answer to immortality or the key to longevity. It seems to be more about being able to birth a new self at the price of the old self. When in this world losing a current and knowledgeable life to bring in a new infant one is reasonable, this jellyfish could be the change in human reproduction at best.

Stu...Before you write stuff, do your research. Medicare sets the rates they pay doctors and the doctors have no say whatsoever in those rates. They already don't cover costs. A doctor can charge a million dollars for something and medicare reimburses the pre-set fees.

The lack of resources to pay medical bills is so large, that in our community people hold fund raisers to pay medical bills.  If we had the kind of medical programs found in Europe, this never would have to happen.  Moreover, according to some polls, the majority of Americans would also like such a plan, but of course, the money invested and made in all aspects of the health care industry in the United States has more control over what our congress does than the people who actually elect them.

Excellent points - the whole "medical industry" gives new meaning to the term "vulture capitalism."

And talk about a captive audience - who doesn't get sick? However past a certain point it's obscene - hundreds of dollars for a pill or 15 minutes of a doctor's time is out of whack with what most people can afford, but also with what's decent.

Why increase the Medicare Pt B premium when you can simply tell the medical industry to chain ITSELF to the actual rise in the cost of living?  The doctors, the hospitals, the insurers and the prescription drug companies have long assumed that- thanks to their lobbyists- they can pretty well raise their prices to whatever level they deem appropriate. No one, whether rich or poor, should have to deplete their life savings in order to save their life.  Our politicians (and our governors most of all) need to tell these people in no uncertain terms that any raise in rates over and above the general rate of inflation must be documented with hard evidence to establish why such an increase is justified.  If the medical industry can't operate in good faith within the context of this "free"-market society let the government take over the whole kit and caboodle as it has in virtually every other part of the industrialized world.

The piece on whether NYC recoups tax credits in jobs created, or on balance loses money neglects to add tourism dollars
.
No one could argue that people from all over the world would still come to the city if no picture had ever been made here, and it seems impossible to quantify what the net effect would be. Yet movies, especially those seen by tens or hundreds of millions, create an allure and cache, a fascination for being in "that place"-- where the star was nearly killed, the love was won, the deadly chase finally ended. In a city with as many iconic landmarks and environments as NYC this translates into money one way or another.

My only objection is the sometimes supercilious and imperial attitudes of of PAs and other staffers who expect you to jump through their hoops even when the production is obviously doing nothing in particular. But I guess that goes with the territory too.

The amount of what goes into a particular local economy is only the second most important question. The primary question is how much money leaves the state to go into the pockets of Hollywood.

If tax credits are such a good idea why are the two leading states in this practice Louisiana and MIchigan? Both states have not exactly been paragons of financial rectitude in the past. Are those two states smarter than all the other states? It defies credulity.

It's an easy sell job for the governor of whatever state. They hold a press conference to announce: "I'm bringing Hollywood to (fill in the place) and we're creating jobs and....." It makes a nice one minute piece on the local nightly news and everyone is happy. What's a lot harder to comprehend is the financial machinations outlined in this fine piece of reporting which does not fit into tiny sound bites or paragraphs (which, btw, is what Hollywood and the politicians desire....the general citizenry not understanding the true nature of this).

I have worked in film production for 25 years and we when we come to town we never even spend our per diem that we are given. The big difference between a tax subsidy (and that's what it is) for Hollywood and a company making a permanent move, as that the latter will have employees that buy houses and pay property taxes and become part of the infrastructure of the community. We Hollywood types keep our money and go back to our place of residence and spend it there.

Mary, your argument makes no sense. What you said can be applied to any business. Should McDonalds get a tax subsidy? They create more jobs and bring in more money than the film industry. What about Walmart? Based on your logic, they should be getting the largest taxpayers subsidies.

Being that I work as an accountant in film production, I KNOW how much money is paid into the local economy and the small businesses that benefit from the industry in New York.  It's literally millions of dollars just for the sets - the building, the decorating alone, before you get to the star salaries or the crew salaries which are good middle class to upper class jobs.  The tax return is double the money spent on the credits.  That has been established by audits which is why the credits have been renewed. The industry draws students into the area colleges to study all aspects of filmmaking and the creative fields tied to it.  Okay it's not brain surgery, but the demand for content is high, it's a low impact industry that feeds into the economy of the city in countless ways.  Without the credits, being that New York is the most expensive city to live or work in, and certainly to film in, it would be difficult to say if filmmaking would be able to continue on the level we have enjoyed since the tax incentives started here.

Hollywood treats state political hacks for the rubes they so clearly are, taking their money with promises of bright lights under which budgets will be magically balanced and thousands of  jobs created. The carnivals that set up in church parking lots and on the fields of volunteer fire departments each summer create more jobs per year than movie-making does.

The biology and evolution of an immortal jellyfish is almost as thought provoking to me as the idea of human immortality. Obviously, the first forms of life were not immortal, yet at some time in evolutionary history a mutation occurred that caused immortality. Therefore, the DNA that is inside the cells dictates immortality. However, if these cells are immortal, then the cells do not divide (or else the jellyfish would continually grow in size), the DNA does not replicate, and the telemerers. Lengthening the telemers in other organisms has caused them to live longer; it makes sense that the jellyfish, without deterioration in the telemeres, lives forever.

Human immortality would be extremely detrimental to our planet and ourselves; it is incomparable to the immortality of the jellyfish. While humans continue to reproduce, our population grows exponentially, clearly as a result of couples having more than two children. These jellyfish seem to not reproduce sexually, or even reproduce many offspring at all. In addition, jellyfish have predators and strict environmental limitations. Humans, on the other hand have the technology to survive and be protected in any environment. If we were to live immortally like the jellyfish, we could reproduce at multiple points in our lifetimes, so Earth would be flooding with humans. This would destroy the nature on Earth and end badly for humans too.

Let's say this was possible in humans. What could this lead to in governments? First, what kind of punishments would have to be created for people that committed acts such as "murder"? What would murder even mean anymore? It would mean that it deletes the previous life of a person, but that person would simply regenerate into a newborn. Would the court decide to put a bullet through the murderer's head to birth them into a newborn? If the newborn grew up to be another murderer, would they actually kill him by burning or disintegrating him? Life would have a different meaning. It would no longer be about survival from diseases, but rather from making moral and correct decisions. This jellyfish could potentially change how the human race is run and every aspect of life.

Instant replay is a satisfactory check on human error, subjectivity, and the perceptive limitations of officials.  But it seems like there are other possible technological innovations that could eliminate some of the guess work from the game.  For example, if there were sensors on either side of the goal line (and even along the sidelines for out-of-bounds and first down calls) that would be triggered by a tiny computer chip inside the football, confirming whether or not the ball passed the line (instead of those stupid plastic pylons), seems both cheap and doable.  Why not adopt computerized referring aids of this sort?  Or is the NFL hesitant to replace their employees with machines (machines that would still be operated by human beings, of course) for union reasons, or hanging on to tradition?  I suspect both are why MLB hasn't exchanged umps for a pitch-tracking system (as they have on television, which often contradicts the call behind the plate).
